comments.commentBody: That is not the cause of the decents in stades, massive ice sheets.  The orbital forcing is well understood.
The actors may have been picking up on the energy in the audience.
I think the 30 min. to 1 hr. at the top of the page refers to how long it takes (including prep time) to make the dish. Recipe does not state how long to cook vegetables.
The time is given at the top, above the photograph.

Suggest folks who missed roasting time and temps go back and read instructions again. All times snd temps are there:

Heat oven to 425 degrees. Toss vegetables with oil, salt, and pepper. Roast, 30 minutes to an hour, stirring at least once or twice during roasting for even cooking and browning.

Melissa Clarke. You need to reed your recipe reviews after you post them for feed back. If people say you didn't give the roasting time for the root vegetables, which you didn't, then you should respond with the roasting time.  Thanks

Wow. Get your nose out of the air. "Lower class people"? Who are they in your book? What a condemnation and stereotype. Shall we pass judgment on you and your life based solely on your income level?
Money - or the lack of it - has nothing to do with it. People from all socioeconomic ranks do both good things and bad. Many families living on the edge live good lives and raise great kids, they just never make the news. And many in the higher income bracket do heinous things but also do not make the news, for different reasons. Try a little compassion and understanding of a situation and for these families that, we, the readers of this article only know the bits and pieces that we are fed by the media.
Sorry for the typos.  Clark and read.

I don't understand Harriet's comment at all. My father, a plain-spoken, Plains-bred schoolteacher, would be considered "lower class" by today's economic standards. We scraped by. He did not beat his children. Thousands upon thousands of those not firmly in the middle class never raise a hand to their children. However, you may recall a number of cases in which upper middle class children killed their children. The first one that comes to my mind was from when I was living in Boston in the 1980sl The owner of the trendy Cambridge Coffee, Tea and Spice House murdered his toddler. More recently, a high-tech guy from that area took out his wife and infant. The mother in this story is guilty of a bad choice - leaving children to mind the children - but believe you me, as a retired schoolteacher myself, this happens across the economic board.
Requiring a signature is worthless security. I often draw a horizontal line through the signature fowl. The clerk never looks at it. I'll bet my flat line looks like your flatline. Security haha.
After having credit card fraud 4 times on three cards last year, I will gladly wait in the TJ's line a bit longer to not have to spend hours re-setting-up my automatic banking.

What good is a chip if they are stolen. anyone can use it immediately till it is reported. I Pin would make this nearly impossible. So Those Banks who do not provide PINs, shame on you. I refrain from printing my Bank but like my Pin #. HOWEVER I CAN NOT USE MY PIN # in the US. WE are so behind in technology when compared with EU Banks and store technology.
I never thought of this happening.  I could see how it could occur - the clerk cannot see your hands.  (But the console instructs you when to remove your card.)

The new chip cards/readers are poorly designed. You have to insert your card and leave it in, instead of simply inserting and then putting it away. Aside from the inconvenience of not being able to swipe and then put the card away, the need to leave the card in can lead to what's known in human factors engineering as a post-completion error. Such errors occur whenever you finish your main task (paying) then need to remember to do something else (removing your card). I have no idea who designed this system, but they clearly were not trained in human factors engineering. The whole thing needs to be scrapped and replaced with something that is faster and does not lead to such errors.

The processing fee that businesses pay are set by their merchant acquirers, not Visa or the banks. Sure, Visa and the banks take a cut, but they don't set the all-in rate. Most businesses pay far less than the 4-6% rate that you site. Instead of complaining to Elizabeth Warren, why don't you shop around for a better rate?  For example, Square charges a flat 2.75% fee.
Plus we got rid of pennies and dollar bills as well.  Why are Americans so set in their ways?

The trouble I have encountered is that one never knows for sure anymore whether to swipe or insert the card.  I've been in stores where the terminal reads "swipe your card" but in fact the clerk says insert the card.  I've been at other stores where, seeing that the terminal will accept an inserted card, I've asked whether I should insert and I've been told to swipe. Now, believe me, I understand this is NO BIG DEAL in the grand scheme of things, and for me it's just another few seconds of perplexity, but i can see where someone a lot more rushed than I, and perhaps more Type A to begin with, could become awfully irritated.

This is the crux of the matter:  the "chip" is an improvement only for the bank, not the retailer or, certainly, the consumer.  If this were a chip + pin system, as in Europe, transactions would be based more on a debit card(which everyone uses) than a credit card (which many people reserve for special occasions), thus eliminating the possibility of monthly interest charges.  As it is, in many European countries this U. S. "chip" is entirely useless ... because there is no pin associated with it.  In fact, the new system completely disables visitors to countries such as The Netherlands, where "swipe" cards are not accepted at almost all retail establishments.  Only hotels, some ATMs, and tourist traps accept such an antiquated form of payment.  If the U.S. were truly a member of the international monetary system and not held hostage by its banks, we would have a chip + pin card AND we would be able to make international electronic transfers of funds without exorbitant fees and needless waiting times.

Wow no kidding?  I had no idea the banks would have to charge less for a PIN credit card transaction.  In that case I agree with vkt that the Times (or somebody) ought to be telling readers about this - not that we look forward to more articles about banks' lack of concern for the customer (rather than the shareholders).

Lee Harrison is pretending to know some power engineering. I associate with the best power engineering professors in the west. He doesn't have it right.

Now somewhere I provided a link to a Brookings paper which states that neither wind nor solar provide the best CO2 abatement; nuclear power is better. Indeed, possibly CCGTs are even better so long as the fraked natgas lasts.

Mr. Hollande is doing what we should have done like two years ago. What would you suggest? Wait and see? Re-educate the entire population of disaffected young men in the Middle East? Great strategy. In the meantime, innocent people will be being murdered, Christians crucified, women sold into sexual slavery, soveriegn states invaded and their cities and territories occupied, irreplaceable cultural relics and monuments destroyed because they are not Muslim.

I think Obama has been trying to extricate the US from "the Decider's" fiasco, and I think that's a good thing.

We can defeat and occupy a country that has an effective central government, like Japan or Germany after WWII. But a country that has no effective central government needs a massive force with soldiers on every corner. In the Middle East, there are a few countries like that, with terrorists in all of them. And the countries that do have central governments (Iran, Saudi Arabia, Pakistan, Russia) are supporting various terrorists, would probably want to undermine our efforts at getting everything under (our) control, and are well placed to do so (Iran warned GWB that they would make everything blow up in his face, he didn't believe them, and they did it, easily).

To manage this mess by force, we'd probably have to invade at least one or two more countries to keep them from interfering with us, and we'd need soldiers on every corner in every country that we were occupying. We probably don't even have enough military age youth in the United States to do this job.

And, most of these are tribal or family based societies, with no concept of nationhood, so as soon as we left, everything would fall apart.

And what would it be for? How many more people should die because GWB wasn't curious enough to read a Lonely Planet Guide to Iraq before invading it? How about you and your family - are you ready to go there and die?

Warrantless raids, house arrest, more surveillance, these all sound like steps that restrict freedom which is exactly the kind of state that ISIS wants to obtain.
The first reaction to terrorism should never involve changing your constitution. That's a little like drunk dialing your ex. Just don't do it.
For a dose of proportion, while the events in France are tragic with 129 deaths in a single night, that same night nearly 100 people in the US died from a gun.
The most ISIS has ever been able to do and are likely able to do in the future is kill unarmed civilians. That's not saying much about their capabilities. This too shall pass.

Mr. Little--Actually, they are a nation holding territory in the Levant exclusively with a government-the caliphate!  They were beaten at Vienna in the 15th century and in WWII and they will be beaten again!
Love drive out hate?  Surely you are delirious.
If Obama won't defend the U.S. or its allies he should be impeached.

If the West avoided certain military tactics in WWII because of fear of failure, mistakes, being politically correct, or public backlash, history might be different today. It's easy to be sitting at home and thinking about all of the idealistically correct things France should do, but Hollande is running the reality of the situation and he's taking the steps he sees necessary. He's the leader, we're not.

I wish all of the leaders of all civilized countries would unite and get on a stage together declaring that they are going to work together to defeat ISIS. Until that happens, ISIS will hang in there and most likely continue to grow despite the efforts of any one nation.

Quite frankly, I think the only reason the West hasn't taken a more bold approach in uniting immediately (militarily speaking) after the Paris attacks is because of the disaster of the Iraq war. Everyone has cold feet, and the world doesn't trust the west in the same way it did pre-Iraq war. Even the west doesn't trust itself in the same way. The Paris attacks were an act of war. France is at war. War isn't pretty. I hope all nations against terrorism can unite. If not, what will it take to do so? A worse attack? How bad does the attack need to be before everyone says, "Enough"?
I am glad you are not a leader of a country that has been attacked 20 year old monstrous kids.

To the President and people of France:

Your fears, your anxieties, your anger, your sense of being violated, those are all perfectly natural responses that we New Yorkers know all too well. But if I may be so presumptuous as to offer just one thought for your consideration: allow your fears to recede a bit, your anxieties to ease, your sense of violation to begin to heal, before you start down the path of passing sweeping legislation or constitutional changes. As many Americans have learned through bitter experience, that path is fraught with dangerous consequences unconsidered and unforeseen, and you may find it very difficult to retrace your steps back to the last fork along the way.
Adrian O is wrong again.  Penn State is so-called state supported while U Penn is private.

The Saudis to help?  Don't you think they have done enough?   After all,  where did the majority of the 9-11 terrorists come from?   Saudi Arabia.   And Bin Laden is from Saudi Arabia,  hmmmmm.  Coincidence?   I wouldn't be surprised if Saudi Arabia is financing ISIS.
